segments.text: ...the oriented support mechanism for oceanography.
This is ONR now?
Yes, sir.
It was the university support for oceanography.
Still is the major one, except for ship support through NSF.
But then they provided ship time, they provided research time.
No, it was not mission oriented.
And it really
It was knowingly that way.
It got support from the admiral.
Because the admiral saw, for example, let me tell you a little story.
When sonar came out, they ran into immediate problems in submarine use of sonar on the continental shelf.
And they didn't know what the dickens it was.
It was like a frying pan.
just crackle, crackle, crackle.
And it was destroying the effectiveness of it.
And they didn't know what it was.
And they put Martin Johnson on it from Scripps, the guy that I've worked with.
But that was before I worked with him.
That was during 1940, 41.
And he found out it was a snapping shrimp.
And he found out about the rhythm, their habits,
He told them where they might expect them and what would set them off and so on.
So some of the admirals knew that this kind of basic research was extremely important to them.
And so at the time, and with the cajoling of Roger and perhaps other people that I am unaware of, not to give him full credit,
decided we don't know where an important finding is going to come from.
And so this was very definitely not a mission-oriented group.
Do you feel that ideally that the major funds for general scientific research in the sea should come from a military affiliated organization such as that, or should it be a separate
Well, let me tell you this.
I don't know that that part is the important thing.
Here was what was important about ONR and may still be.
That is that they had a group of competent people who could judge whether or not work that was being done was good work of its kind or not.

If they could put together this small team of people who had the executive and administrative ability and the financial ability, they could put together a research program which made sense, which was coherent.
This is more difficult when you go to an institution such as NSF, where you've got a physical oceanography program, you see, and you had a biological and a chemical.
There is no doubt that NSF has supported some of the best oceanographic work ever done, but not in the way ONR could do it.
They couldn't put together a package without making that a big thing.
And that's what I think destroyed some of the work in oceanography is that everything went to big operations, big cooperative ventures.
Now, some of this is necessary for synopticity and physical oceanography.
It's necessary to have several vessels and bring satellites and the whole bit into it.
But it is not for others.
It is having people that you know are working on this facet.
And this team had an overview so they could put together this one working on this facet.
And they came up with a coherent program, which I think was good.
Now, it's still being done, I suppose.
But NSF didn't ever develop that capacity.
Theirs was wholly a peer group analysis and evaluation.
Whereas there was practically no peer group in ONR unless they wanted to have that kind of evaluation.
They could fall back on it.
But they had the ability to go out and say, you are doing good work.
We like what you're doing.
We want to give you support, like that.
Give us a proposal.
NSF can't do that, at least
It hasn't.
They can't do that or they don't do that?
Well, they may do it.
They may do it, but pretty much they don't dare go around their panels, their evaluation panels.
If they do, they're going to get in trouble.
Don't you think that's true of all federally?
NAW, National Endowment for the Humanities, or any of these, we're pretty well rigidly controlled by our referees on the panels themselves.
Yes, there's been a lot of buddy system in it, too.
And this has been one of the problems, is that it was very difficult for people at one point to break into the circle.
Fortunately, you see, in 1960, Texas A&M was getting practically nothing out of NSA.
But in 1976, they're getting a lot out of Minnesota.
And part of the reason for that is that people transferred from one institution here to another and brought this kind of aura with them.
And it's made a difference.
I'd like to ask another question on that line.
We have noticed that in people who've joined the A&M faculty, that is yourself, Captain Treadwell,
Professor Geyer seemed to have come with contacts in ONR, in NSL, in private enterprise, so that they could bring with them grants.
Do you think that's a deliberate hiring policy?
It was at first, clearly was, and still is in most institutions.
I got associated with ONR
And as a consequence, I never ask NSF for anything other than a few hundred dollars once to support a student on a very special sort of thing.
When this book is finished, I'm going to write them my first proposal for research in the deep sea.
And I'm still going to finish it.
I've been invited by several people
there to come back and discuss ideas with them, which I suppose would lead to proposals.
But I just didn't need the support.
ONR was giving me all I could use effectively.
And now we're getting off on these Mickey Mouse things with the Bureau of Land Management, which I'm not too keen on.
It's pretty short, fused.
telescopic vision kind of work.
Are you speaking of the work in lignite?
No, this is Bureau of Land Management work on the Outer Continental Shelf, a preparatory to drilling for oil.
I just happen to have a few questions I wanted to ask you about that while we're here.
What do you consider, work on the Continental Shelf, what do you consider the role that private enterprise ought to have to play in the financing of

oceanography's activity vis-a-vis the bureau of land management well in a way they're doing it but it's indirect right now they're supporting most of it the way they're supporting it is by buying these lease rights on the outer continental shelf from the bureau of land management
to the tune of one on Destin Dome was $212 million, and they got no oil out of it.
So in actual fact, the oil companies are now supporting an immense amount of research through this indirect means.
I therefore feel that mines better than mine should decide whether they should do more direct support.
Theirs is very definitely mission-oriented work.
For example, the state of California is now imposing additional restrictions on them.
Prior to drilling, they must do certain kinds of environmental studies, even though baseline studies have been done previously.
Do you consider this good?
No, I don't.
I think that if we carry this too far, it will destroy the environmental programs.
And the pendulum swings no matter what you try to do, and it's gone much too far, in my opinion, of stringency on environmental concerns.
Do you agree with Spilhaus that the sea belongs to all countries equally, that is, opposed to the concept of a 200-mile line?
I assume that to me.
That question is one that
I can't answer off the cuff, and I have not really thought about it.
Okay, well... Philosophically, one would have to answer in the affirmative, but I think there are many other factors that have to be considered on that.
Would you like to comment on that in, let's say, in light of the continental shells and your work there?
Well, I'll tell you.
I'm not sure that the continental shelf is the only place we're ever going to get anything of value out of the ocean.
But obviously, it's the easier part to work on right at the moment.
So it is the place that's getting all the attention.
I don't know whether you know, but Professor Darnell and I have cooked up a symposium on the ecology and management of the continental shelf.
Have you learned about that?
Well, at any rate, we've got that cooking.
And in it, I have just invited, as a
member of a panel, the legal counsel for all of the oil industry working on the Continental Shelf from Alaska to Maine.
I just carried on a long conversation with him in New Orleans over the phone on where the environmental movement is going vis-a-vis the oil industry.
And he should provide some interesting
material on that come this symposium in May, June.

I also have, well, Darnell and I, but these happen to be people I've invited, the senior scientist of USGS who has strong ideas about the environmental movement in oil, and we're going to have a gay time over there with these guys roaring around at each other.
So I've given a good deal of thought

The thing that I am sorry about is that we are not able to capitalize on the funds available through, for example, the Bureau of Land Management for gaining the kind of information that I spoke about earlier required for effective management of the shelf.
We are still going out with short fuse work
And by that I mean you're given the grant today and you've got to start working tomorrow.
And it is a contract work.
It is not grant work, which means that if they tell you to collect 20 samples, you've got to collect 20 samples or you're in trouble with the contract.
This is not the way to take advantage of this excellent opportunity to do very good work on the commercial.
There is a study coming down the pike

that someone is going to get, I don't know who, studying the Chenier Plain between Vermilion Bay and Galveston Bay from the plus five contour to the minus 100 foot contour, or isobat, in an attempt to understand the total interplay between the ocean and the marsh and the inner ecological
affecting areas.
And this is a 26-month study in the initial part.
And it is amply funded and will provide for the interaction of physical scientists, biological scientists, social scientists, including economists, sociologists.
This is the kind of thing.
that I think will lead to effective utilization and management of this multi-purpose area we've got.
And what a nice area to do it in, this relatively untouched area.
Very few people have been to the coast between Bolivar and the Birmingham Bay.
What institutions are competing for that?
I think there's only one academic institution and two engineering consortia.
I think LSU, there were 22, and it's been eliminated down now to three left, and two engineering firms.
And I'm a consultant to one of them, or to be, if they get it.
That's not Tereco, is it?
No.
No, it's not.
But I am a consultant to a Canadian firm and a...
an eastern firm.
And they both have asked me if I would help them if they get it.
Would you describe and tell me what TerraEco is?
TerraEco?
Well, that's a low-profile avenue for me to consult when I feel like doing it now and then.
But primarily, I'm hoping to build this to a retirement point
where I can do the kind of research I think ought to be done and fund it myself.
I've been asked to consult and I've turned down most of it.
And right now I'm just turning in a permission to consult for a group.
I suppose I've been asked for maybe $500,000 worth of consulting that I could have done in the last three or four years.
Mostly I turned all of this over to two of my former students who are now working in Taraco, plus some other people that associate now and then.
It was an attempt primarily, originally, to develop a tract of land so that people could live on it somewhat more effectively than
A track developer generally develops land.
Well, that got to be kind of a burden.
And so when I got calls to appear in public, and it didn't look like it was very appropriate to represent the university, I thought, why don't I do that through Taraco?
So I did some in 73, 74, and some in 75.
And we got some grants now and then that people don't want the university involved in.
Now, I might run that through Taraco if, by any chance, these other people got this Chenier plane thing.
They didn't invite the universities for the most part.
They invited LSU, I think, as about the only university.
This was US Fish and Wildlife Service that came up with it.
But I've had very pleasant experiences with that.
But we can't advertise.
We're not trying to make much out of it.
Those things where they come to us directly and ask.
As this group in St. Croix called me and said, would you appear for us in court?
We're being sued as a class suit against this oil spill problem that occurred in 1971.
And, well, I cannot represent the university.
So the affiliation I will give to get around that is I'm affiliated with TerraCo.
even though I got permission from the university to do it.
Makes it a little easier that way.
It is a consulting firm of low key, low stature.
Anything that I invent, for the most part, I would probably run through there.
I've invented a couple of things.
I've got a device which I call the Biotal Ocean Monitor.
before pollution studies in the ocean are chronic type.
And I'm running that through Terrico.
I don't think it belongs in the University of Franklin.
And I don't have any retirement at the University particularly, so I'm just sort of building up toward my retirement.
Do you think in these kinds of studies that there's a conflict between private enterprise and universities?
I don't mean Terrico.
I mean work that will involve private enterprise and the university and the study, for example, of the marshlands on the Texas coast that you're talking about.
Yes, I do feel that the university is doing too many things now that they should not be doing.
And Jack Williams and John Calhoun notwithstanding, I think that, let me cite this as an example.
Routine things that are done by the university ought better to be done by industry, by private enterprise.
They are jamming the research capacity of the chemistry department.
Not to speak about somebody else's department, but they are jamming with requests or actual work being done.
Simple routine analyses for hydrocarbons in the environment.
Now what value is this to a research-oriented institution?
Unless you can make some use of it.

The university should never get, if it's a state university in my opinion, in crossfire between the federal government and the state, where it has from time to time taken a research, so-called research activity, and they have got into a framework where the state has a vested interest and so has the federal government.
It is a state institution receiving federal support as well.
And they come out.
And if they rule, they go one way or the other.
And they're going to make an enemy on one side or the other.
And I think the university should be out of that.
I think that the university in the main, things done by consulting firms today should not be approached by the university.
They are destroying their opportunities to do the esoteric kind of thing that we don't know where it leads now.
Are you referring then specifically to the extension services that are open?
No, not alone to that.
No, not alone.
That may be, in agriculture, may be a necessary service to be performed.
Maybe there aren't private groups that do that so much.
But certainly, I'm talking about

Some of the work we do in oceanography, for example, just plain routine stuff, going back time after time, taking grain size analysis samples or certain biological samples, where we aren't going to learn anything since we've done it repeatedly.
Who is this being done for then, this routine type work?
Well, Bureau of Land Management is one of them.
USGS.
Police departments.
Whole lot of people.
We've got an analytical services laboratory.
This is fine.
But it ought to really be backing up research activities in the university much more than some of these others.
Now, that's one man's view, obviously.
But it's one I've thought about a good deal.
Well, I wanted to ask you to evaluate the role of academic programs today in sciences.
And you partially already answered this.
Do you think they're becoming too specifically oriented towards practical research or applied sciences rather than theoretical research or theoretical sciences?
Well, there has to be a happy balance in instruction as opposed to the research aspects of instruction.
There has to be a happy balance between
the theoretical and the applied and practical.
Because we do have to think of our students and what they face.
They've got to have enough experience in practical matters to aid them if that is the kind of job open to them.
Today, not all of them can go into the academic world.
There's no doubt of that.
And so we have to have that.
This is a distinct question from the other one of the role of the practical in terms of the use of your facility.
Should a $300,000 piece of equipment, analytical equipment be used to solve

the needs of routine water analysis for petroleum hydrocarbons, or should it be used for the research activities which are exploring much more than just whether the compound is there and in what quantity, but what it is actually doing by being there.
These are two entirely different approaches to the same compound.
And I think the university ought to be working on the latter.
In your career, what has been your more favorite, I should think?
That's very poorly put.
Or what type of research would you say you enjoyed the more, deep ocean research or deep sea research?
I've had two things that have been extremely attractive to me, both of which
through probably poor personal discipline, have led into very difficult problems for which I may not be fully prepared.
But both are still admirably intriguing and soul satisfying.
The deep sea is very difficult to study.
But it is, it's been one of the thrilling experiences of my life to work that way and to have been with students during these cruises when, you know, we all shared the same excitement.
But also this work in shallower water on these rock reefs, I still feel I've been letting it mellow now for some time, but it's all
I still feel that these extremely complex populations on these submarine rock reefs are going to yield insights into ecology that we have not yet codified.
And I'm just hoping that I can maintain my mental faculties long enough to have sufficient time to really
go somewhere where you can get away from this and really think about it.
You know, it's sort of like, well, daily distractions are nowhere to enter the plan for thoughtful work.
You know, you come to a point where you can no longer just grind it out on a computer.
You've got to think about it.
And that's where I am with some of this.
I can just about see that it's there, but I can't get it.
And I don't know what it's going to take associating with other people.
Maybe this symposium, you know.
There'll be enough stimulation of people coming all together in a couple of gold sessions.
You might just hit on what you want.
I know there's something I want there.
But David C. had the same problem when he wanted to write the sea.
He said, I had to get away from the sea.
I went way inland to do it, because you can't.
The sea is an overwhelming experience.
It comes back to that emotionality and identification I talked about.
How would you explain your interest in the crustacea that you specialize in and the systematics there?
How does that fit in?
This was something that I wanted to do.
that I'd never done, is describe a new species.
I wanted the experience of doing this.
And I'd always been intrigued by this since studying in that history of science course Carl Linnaeus, or Carolus Linnaeus, you know, who was the starter of modern systematics.
I'd always wanted the experience.
This was a group no one was working on.
I couldn't get anybody to identify them.
Was it from a practical need that you needed... Yeah, and so I said, this group, and they intrigued me, these little rascals, too.
They seem to have beautiful isopathic limits.
That is, they are restricted depth-wise.
And so, and since we were getting a lot, we were getting things that a lot of deep-sea biologists with this equipment and this monster trawl, I was getting stuff people just hadn't seen before.
Now, Robert Menzies is...

is an eminent deep-sea biologist, but when he came over here and looked at some of our collection, he'd never seen some of these things because the Menzies trawl he was working with just didn't get him.
Well, that's nothing against Menzies, but it just turns out that he didn't know.
Now, one of my former students, Gil Rowe at Woods Hole, he goes down in the deep submersible and
takes a look at him with his eyes.
But I've still got organisms I've collected, and big ones.
I have never been able to photograph them.
Every other major group of animals
